On Thu, 23 Jan 2003, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:

> >But in the end, I guess you believe in test-first programming or you
> don't.
>
> Not necessarily. There's no TDD licence. You can do it sometimes and
> not other times. I only wish that those who choose this approach
> measure the difference between the two.

Well, for me the measure is pretty easy. I no longer spend ten minutes
working out the interface for a class only to discover that it's a nice
interface, but not the interface I need.

In fact, quite often these days, I find myself practicing "test-second,
implementation-third" programming. I'll be in the middle of programming
a servlet, and I'll realize I need to be able to find, say, a Foo object
based on the current IP address of the request. At that point, I'll just
make up, on the spot, the most convenient interface for that, and use
it, even though that interface, and possibly not even the object I'm
using, exists.

After I've finished coding my little routine, the actual code that gets
and uses the foo object is written and right in front of me, so I know
the interface. Unfortunately, at this point I can't test because my
Foo stuff doesn't exist. So then I code up enough of Foo (usually just
a mock object with specific behaviour) to let me test the routine I'm
working on, and work out some way to get it into the routine I'm working
on during unit testing. Now I can test the method I'm working on, and
make any changes necessary for it to pass. (This may change the Foo
interface as well.) Eventually my current little bit of work is done and
tested, even though the code it depends on doesn't even exist yet!

After all this is done, I can then go and create the Foo thingie that
really should exist based on the code that uses it. So I write up tests
based on the code, and then code and test the Foo thingie itself.

I've found many advantages to this approach:

1. It lets you concentrate on and finish one thing at a time, rather
than getting into a big "stack" of things, where you are constantly
pushing down the current activity to start a new one. This means that
in a limited amount of time, you can complete two things rather than
half-complete four, and you don't suffer from the "now where was I?"
problem when you "pop the stack."

2. Interfaces are worked out where they need to be worked out, in the
users of that interface. Speculative coding is reduced.

3. When you get to testing an interface, the tests tend to be easier to
work out, because you've got all the examples of how the inteface is
used right in front of you.

4. Tests are localized to particular classes and areas of code, rather
than depending on other classes and areas of code working correctly.

5. The need for test coverage is reduced, because you can not write
tests for functionality you never use. (This needs to be applied with
caution, of course; if your interface offers unused functionality and
you've not tested it, someone else later might use that functionality,
assuming it's tested, and run into bugs. But then again, it's not good
practice for interfaces to offer functionality that's not used, anyway.)

I used to be a very bottom-up programmer, but the speed and ease of this
top-down approach has completely converted me. I now write probably one
half to one third the amount of code I used to write to get equivalant
functionality in an application. My customers really appreciate this.
